header.title: The Scroll of Set - Issue Number 143, Volume XXII-1, February 1996
header.category: Western Esotericism, Left-Hand Path, Setian Philosophy, Modern Occultism, Magical Practice

central_thesis: This issue of The Scroll of Set functions as a dynamic repository of Setian philosophy and practical Black Magic. It collectively posits that individual self-deification (Xeper) is achieved through conscious will, the cultivation of 'worthy pride,' systematic self-mastery, and the integration of diverse magical traditions (Tarot, Runes, Enochian, Egyptian concepts) interpreted through a uniquely Setian, anti-dogmatic framework. The overarching goal is continuous personal evolution and manifestation, transcending conventional limitations and external influences.

structure_content.summary: Defines Setian pride as a noble, self-sufficient quality derived from knowledge of the higher self, distinct from arrogance or contempt. Lucifer serves as a role model for the Black Magician who exalts the self, rejecting conformity and embracing 'Coming Into Being' to Remanifest noble aspects. Protocol is viewed as a means to promote this prideful outlook.

structure_content.chapter_title: [3] Xeper through the Images of Death and Life, beyond the Mortality of the Grave
structure_content.summary: Explores death as a form of 'Xeper' for the Black Magician, a conscious, subjective awakening into 'higher unlife' beyond the physical body. It contrasts RHP death (annihilation in Osiris) with LHP death (awakening in Sokaris or Remanifestation in subjective universes), advocating for conscious mastery over the transition.

Introduces a Tarot spread named after the Egyptian goddess Ma'at, symbolizing the self's focused effort to achieve balance among options, environment, and inner life. It provides instructions for its use in divination and as a ritual tool for initiating personal change, emphasizing self-reliance over prophetic fatalism.

Explores the Aztec deity Tezcatlipoca ('Smoking Mirror') as embodying the human shadow-self and a catalyst for success. It links this concept to the Enochian system via John Dee's 'Shew Stone' and the 'Word of Set,' aiming to revive shamanic techniques for undermining assumed truths and accessing hidden knowledge within a Setian context.

Focuses on psychological self-programming, particularly the Reticular Activation System (RAS), to achieve magical and mundane goals. It stresses the importance of positive thought, conscious focus, and 'doing the work' through interim goals and written affirmations for self-image transformation.

Describes the creation and charging of 'magical beacons' (e.g., engraved stones) as personal tools to store, reflect, and filter magical energies. These beacons serve to provide energetic boosts and protection from negative influences, emphasizing a Setian, personalized approach to amulet/talisman creation.

Discusses the Runa system, specifically raidho, uruz, naudhiz, and ansuz, as a 'map of Becoming' and a path for Xeper. These runes symbolize stages of rational knowledge, vital experience, tested struggle, and divine understanding, guiding the Setian's evolutionary journey and the manifestation of subjective will into objective reality.

Presents a Setian understanding of time, distinguishing between cyclical 'pa' (core self, 'time before time'), spiraling 'Neheh' (futurity, actions of the psyche, awareness), and linear 'Djet' (objective past). It provides exercises for interacting with these time streams to facilitate Remanifestation and personal evolution.

Interprets the Enochian system, particularly the Heptarchia Mystica and Elemental Tablets, through a Setian lens, divesting it from Cabalistic and Golden Dawn accretions. The system is viewed as representing the self's powers of creation, initiation, and mastery over one's environment, culminating in the 'Word of Set' as its purer form.

key_concepts.definition: The core Setian concept of self-deification, or 'Coming Into Being,' through conscious, willed evolution and expansion of self-consciousness, transcending limitations. It is an unceasing, dynamic process of transformation.
The unique spark of isolated self-consciousness inherent in each Setian, distinguishing them from the 'blind, mindless mass' and driving their individual evolutionary path.

The willed, conscious recurrence and strengthening of ideas, qualities, or aspects of the self, often linked to the manipulation of internal time streams to bring desired outcomes into being stronger and better.

A noble, self-sufficient state of being derived from knowledge of the higher self, embodying dignity and nobility, as opposed to arrogance or contempt. It is a fundamental characteristic of 'Coming Into Being'.

A neurological concept adapted for magical practice, referring to the brain's filtering system that can be consciously programmed to focus on goals, opportunities, and the path of Xeper, facilitating the attainment of magical and mundane objectives.

Interpreted not as objective cosmic balance, but as the self's willful focusing of options, environment, and inner life to achieve a personal, subjective balance, symbolizing clarity of vision, balanced perception, and careful judgment in the context of self-evolution.

An ancient Egyptian god personifying life in death, reinterpreted as the Setian soul's 'end' as another beginning—a conscious Remanifestation beyond physical mortality, representing consciousness, awakening, and freedom in death.

Skillful psychological manipulation, perception management, and practical application of occult principles for personal advantage, often involving cunning and a deliberate display of control to influence others' sensibilities.

A tripartite understanding of time: 'Pa' is the cyclical 'time before time' where Xeper originates; 'Neheh' is the spiraling 'futurity' or 'eternity' representing the psyche's active processes; 'Djet' is the linear 'fixed boundary' of the objective past. Setians aim to manipulate Neheh to influence Remanifestation.

practical_system.description: The document outlines a multi-faceted and individually tailored system of Black Magic focused on Xeper (self-deification). It integrates conscious will, psychological self-mastery (e.g., programming the RAS), ritual work, and reinterpreted traditions (Egyptian, Enochian, Runes, Tarot) to achieve internal transformation and external manifestation. The approach is experimental and personal, emphasizing continuous self-evolution, rejection of external dogma, and active engagement with one's unique magical path to transcend limitations.
tools: Magical beacons (e.g., polished river stones, sculptures)
Writing tools (for RAS programming, goal documentation)
rituals: Ma'at Tarot Spread (divination and change initiation)
Eternal Net Working (group ritual for understanding principles)
Magical Beacon Creation (charging objects for energy storage/filtration)
Runa Workshop (e.g., Hammer Rite for understanding Becoming)
Time Magic Exercises (drawing spirals/lines to manipulate Pa, Neheh, Djet)
Enochian Work (using Calls/Keys for self-creation and mastery)

relevant_quotes.text: No, worthy pride is an inescapable characteristic of Coming Into Being.
The Temple of Set is locked in a state of perpetual motion. Its Xeper is unceasing.

Our death is not in Osiris, for we seek not to become one with any other thing but our own divine selves. The Setian soul will find his 'end' but another beginning, and can be one of life in death, as is personified by the ancient Egyptian god Sokaris.
If every day you wake up and say to yourself 'I am a Black Magician. Today my power will grow, and I will be as Set.', then this is what will occur - provided you do the 'work'.
In the dark are many runes. On Hel's road much is hidden. Seek, seek, seek the mysteries, and in so doing Become yourself.
The magician learns to dream outside of his head.

critical_analysis.relevance: This issue is highly relevant for understanding the historical and ongoing philosophical and practical developments within the Temple of Set. It serves as a primary source for specific Setian interpretations of core occult concepts (e.g., Enochian magic, time, death) and the application of psychological principles (RAS) to magical practice. The emphasis on individual self-deification, conscious will, and the dynamic nature of Xeper positions it as a foundational text for practitioners and scholars interested in Left-Hand Path traditions and modern esotericism, demonstrating how these concepts were actively being explored and integrated by Setian Initiates in the mid-1990s.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of Initiates and aspirants of the Temple of Set, seeking to deepen their understanding and practice of Setian philosophy and Black Magic. It is also valuable for scholars of Western Esotericism, Left-Hand Path traditions, and practitioners of modern occultism interested in the unique philosophical and operative systems developed by the Temple of Set, offering insights into a contemporary magical current.
